playbooks.title: A beginner's playbook to cyber security
playbooks.summary: In this beginner playbook, created by a beginner XD, We learn on how to choose cyber security as your career and break into the entry level barrier and be a part of the blue team
playbooks.content:
Cybersecurity Entry Playbook

Objective

To provide a comprehensive, step-by-step guide for individuals aiming to start a career in cybersecurity.

Scope

This playbook is intended for beginners with little to no experience in cybersecurity and IT professionals looking to transition into the cybersecurity field.

Step 1: Assess Interest and Aptitude

1.1 Understand Cybersecurity

  • Research: Read articles, watch videos, and listen to podcasts about the cybersecurity industry to understand what it involves.
  • Explore Roles: Familiarize yourself with different roles within cybersecurity (e.g., Security Analyst, Penetration Tester, Incident Responder, Security Consultant).
  • Self-Assessment:
  • Use tools like the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) or DISC Profile to assess your suitability for various roles.
  • Reflect on your interests in problem-solving, attention to detail, and technology.

1.2 Determine Your Learning Style

  • Visual Learners: Seek out video courses and visual guides.
  • Auditory Learners: Listen to cybersecurity podcasts and webinars.
  • Kinesthetic Learners: Engage in hands-on labs and practical exercises.

1.3 Set Goals

  • Short-Term: Learn basic concepts and identify the role you want to pursue.
  • Long-Term: Obtain certifications, gain experience, and land your first cybersecurity job.

Step 2: Acquire Basic Knowledge

2.1 Learn Basic IT Concepts

  • Networking: Understand the fundamentals of networking, including IP addresses, subnets, and protocols.
  • Recommended Courses: CompTIA Network+
  • Operating Systems: Learn the basics of Windows, Linux, and macOS.
  • Recommended Resources:
  • Linux: The Linux Command Line
  • Windows: Microsoft's Windows IT Pro Center

2.2 Cybersecurity Foundations

  • Security Basics: Learn about key concepts like Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability (CIA triad), and basic security measures.
  • Recommended Course: CompTIA Security+
  • Threats and Vulnerabilities: Study common cybersecurity threats such as malware, phishing, and DDoS attacks.

2.3 Study Resources

  • Books:
  • “Cybersecurity for Beginners” by Raef Meeuwisse
  • “The Web Application Hacker’s Handbook” by Dafydd Stuttard and Marcus Pinto
  • Blogs:
  • Krebs on Security
  • Schneier on Security
  • Podcasts:
  • Darknet Diaries
  • The CyberWire

Step 3: Build Technical Skills

3.1 Programming Languages

  • Python: Learn Python for scripting and automation.
  • Recommended Course: Automate the Boring Stuff with Python
  • Bash/Shell Scripting: Master basic shell scripting for automation on Linux systems.
  • JavaScript: Basic understanding for web security-related roles.

3.2 Hands-On Practice

  • Virtual Labs:
  • TryHackMe: TryHackMe
  • Hack The Box: Hack The Box
  • Capture The Flag (CTF) Competitions: Participate in CTF challenges to practice your skills.
  • Platform: CTFtime

3.3 Networking and Security Tools

  • Wireshark: Learn to analyze network traffic.
  • Nmap: Master network scanning and enumeration.
  • Metasploit: Basic understanding for penetration testing.

Step 4: Obtain Certifications

4.1 Entry-Level Certifications

  • CompTIA Security+: Validates foundational cybersecurity knowledge.
  • Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH): Focuses on ethical hacking skills.
  • Cisco Certified CyberOps Associate: Provides a strong foundation in cybersecurity operations.

4.2 Intermediate Certifications

  • Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP): Comprehensive certification for advanced cybersecurity professionals.
  • Certified Information Security Manager (CISM): Management-focused certification.
  • Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA): Focuses on auditing, control, and assurance.

4.3 Specialized Certifications

  • Certified Cloud Security Professional (CCSP): For those interested in cloud security.
  • Offensive Security Certified Professional (OSCP): Advanced penetration testing certification.

Step 5: Gain Practical Experience

5.1 Internships

  • Seek Internships: Apply for cybersecurity internships at companies, focusing on roles that offer hands-on experience.
  • Resources: Internship Platforms, LinkedIn, company websites.

5.2 Volunteer Opportunities

  • Non-Profit Organizations: Offer cybersecurity services to non-profits or open-source projects.
  • Bug Bounty Programs: Participate in bug bounty programs to gain real-world experience and earn rewards.
  • Platforms: HackerOne, Bugcrowd

5.3 Community Involvement

  • Join Cybersecurity Communities: Engage in forums, attend meetups, and participate in discussions.
  • Communities: OWASP, ISACA, ISC2

Step 6: Build a Professional Network

6.1 Networking Events

  • Conferences: Attend cybersecurity conferences to meet professionals and learn from experts.
  • Examples: DEF CON, Black Hat, RSA Conference.
  • Webinars and Meetups: Participate in online and in-person cybersecurity events.

6.2 LinkedIn

  • Profile Optimization: Ensure your LinkedIn profile reflects your skills, certifications, and interests.
  • Connect with Professionals: Reach out to industry professionals, join groups, and seek mentorship.

6.3 Mentorship

  • Find a Mentor: Seek out experienced professionals who can guide you.
  • Be a Mentee: Learn from their experiences, ask for advice, and apply their feedback.

Step 7: Prepare for Job Applications

7.1 Resume Preparation

  • Tailor Your Resume: Highlight your certifications, hands-on experience, and relevant skills.
  • Showcase Projects: Include links to projects or labs you've worked on.
  • Quantify Achievements: Use metrics to showcase your impact (e.g., "Reduced system vulnerabilities by 30%").

7.2 Interview Preparation

  • Mock Interviews: Practice with friends, mentors, or through platforms like Pramp.
  • Technical Interviews: Focus on problem-solving, network security, and scenario-based questions.
  • Behavioral Interviews: Prepare to discuss your experience, problem-solving approach, and teamwork.

7.3 Job Search

  • Job Boards: Use specialized job boards for cybersecurity roles.
  • Examples: CyberSecJobs, Indeed, LinkedIn
  • Company Websites: Apply directly on the websites of companies you're interested in.

Step 8: Apply for Jobs

8.1 Application Strategy

  • Apply Broadly: Don't limit yourself to a single role; explore various entry-level positions.
  • Customize Applications: Tailor each application to the job description.

8.2 Follow-Up

  • After Interviews: Send thank-you emails and follow up if you don't hear back.
  • Persistence: Keep applying and refining your approach based on feedback.

8.3 Accepting Offers

  • Evaluate Offers: Consider the role, company culture, growth opportunities, and benefits.
  • Negotiate Salary: Be prepared to negotiate based on market rates and your qualifications.

Tools and Resources

Learning Platforms

  • Udemy: Cybersecurity Courses
  • LinkedIn Learning: Security Training
  • Coursera: Cybersecurity Specializations

Books

  • “Hacking: The Art of Exploitation” by Jon Erickson
  • “Security Engineering” by Ross Anderson
  • “The Phoenix Project” by Gene Kim, Kevin Behr, and George Spafford

Communities and Forums

  • Reddit: r/cybersecurity
  • Stack Overflow: Security Tags
  • Discord Groups: Cybersecurity-focused channels (e.g., The Cybersecurity Lounge)

Review and Update Procedures

  • Regular Reviews: Reassess your goals, skills, and progress every 6 months.
  • Update Playbook: Modify steps, tools, and resources as the cybersecurity field evolves.
  • Continuous Learning: Stay updated with the latest trends, threats, and technologies in cybersecurity.

playbooks.title: Phishing Awareness and Response Playbook
playbooks.summary: To educate employees on how to recognize and respond to phishing attempts effectively, reducing the risk of successful phishing attacks.
playbooks.content:
Phishing Awareness and Response Playbook

Objective

To educate employees on how to recognize and respond to phishing attempts effectively, reducing the risk of successful phishing attacks.

Step 1: Education

1.1 Conduct Regular Training Sessions

  • Frequency: Schedule mandatory training sessions quarterly.
  • Content:
  • Overview of phishing and its impact.
  • Detailed examples of phishing tactics and techniques.
  • Interactive elements such as quizzes and simulations.
  • Delivery Methods:
  • In-Person: Workshops or seminars led by cybersecurity experts.
  • Online: E-learning modules accessible at employees’ convenience.
  • Webinars: Live sessions with Q&A opportunities.

1.2 Provide Examples of Phishing Emails

  • Realistic Scenarios: Share examples of common phishing emails, including fake job offers, account alerts, and urgent requests.
  • Annotated Examples: Highlight and explain suspicious elements in sample phishing emails.
  • Phishing Simulations: Conduct simulated phishing attacks to test and reinforce employee awareness.

Step 2: Recognition

2.1 Teach Employees to Identify Phishing Indicators

  • Suspicious Links:
  • Check URLs carefully for misspellings or unusual domain names.
  • Hover over links to preview URLs before clicking.
  • Sender Addresses:
  • Verify the sender’s email address for legitimacy.
  • Be cautious of addresses with slight misspellings of legitimate domains.
  • Unusual Requests:
  • Watch for requests for sensitive information or immediate action.
  • Be skeptical of unexpected attachments or links.
  • Urgency and Threats:
  • Recognize and question emails that create a sense of urgency or fear.

2.2 Practice Safe Email Habits

  • Avoid Clicking Links: Encourage employees to type URLs directly into the browser rather than clicking on links.
  • Verify Suspicious Emails: Advise employees to verify requests by contacting the sender through an alternative method.

Step 3: Reporting

3.1 Establish a Clear Reporting Process

  • Reporting Procedures:
  • Outline step-by-step instructions for reporting phishing attempts.
  • Designate a specific point of contact or team for handling reports.
  • Training on Reporting: Ensure employees are familiar with the reporting process through training and reminders.

3.2 Create a Phishing Email Address

  • Dedicated Address: Set up a dedicated email address (e.g., phishing@company.com) for reporting phishing attempts.
  • Automated Response: Implement an automated response to confirm receipt of the report and provide initial guidance.

Step 4: Response

4.1 Analyze Reported Emails

  • Initial Assessment: Evaluate reported emails to determine if they are phishing attempts.
  • Incident Response:
  • Containment: Quarantine affected emails and assess potential impact.
  • Investigation: Investigate the source and method of the phishing attempt.
  • Mitigation: Implement measures to prevent similar attacks.

4.2 Implement Email Filters and Security Tools

  • Email Filtering:
  • Configure email filters to identify and block known phishing sources.
  • Use advanced filtering techniques to detect suspicious content.
  • Security Tools:
  • Implement and update anti-phishing and anti-malware tools.
  • Deploy email authentication protocols such as SPF, DKIM, and DMARC.

Step 5: Follow-Up

5.1 Inform Employees About Confirmed Phishing Attempts

  • Notifications: Send notifications to employees about confirmed phishing attempts, including details and any actions required.
  • Lessons Learned: Share insights and lessons from the incident to reinforce training.

5.2 Reinforce Training and Awareness

  • Regular Updates: Provide updates on new phishing tactics and reinforce best practices.
  • Continuous Improvement: Regularly update training materials and phishing simulations based on emerging threats and feedback.

5.3 Review and Improve Processes

  • Incident Review: Conduct reviews of phishing incidents and response effectiveness.
  • Playbook Updates: Update the playbook to reflect changes in phishing tactics, technologies, and organizational needs.

Tools and Resources

Training Platforms

  • Online Courses: KnowBe4, SANS Security Awareness
  • Simulations: PhishMe, Wombat Security

Security Tools

  • Email Security Solutions: Proofpoint, Mimecast
  • Filtering Solutions: Barracuda, Cisco IronPort

Communication Channels

  • Internal Communication: Use company intranet or internal newsletters to communicate phishing awareness.
  • Feedback Mechanisms: Implement surveys or feedback forms to gather employee input on phishing awareness and response effectiveness.

Review and Update Procedures

Regular Reviews

  • Frequency: Review the playbook and training materials annually or after major phishing incidents.
  • Feedback Integration: Incorporate feedback from employees and incident reports to enhance the playbook.

Continuous Improvement

  • Stay Informed: Keep up with the latest phishing trends and adjust training and response strategies accordingly.
  • Update Procedures: Regularly update reporting and response procedures based on new threats and technologies.

playbooks.title: A Basic Vulnerability Management Playbook
playbooks.summary: Establish a systematic and continuous process for identifying, assessing, prioritizing, and mitigating vulnerabilities within the IT environment, thereby reducing the risk of exploitation and ensuring the security of the organization’s assets.
playbooks.content:
Vulnerability Management Playbook

Objective

To establish a systematic and continuous process for identifying, assessing, prioritizing, and mitigating vulnerabilities within the IT environment, thereby reducing the risk of exploitation and ensuring the security of the organization’s assets.

Step 1: Identification

1.1 Run Regular Vulnerability Scans

  • Frequency:
  • Regular Scans: Conduct automated vulnerability scans at least monthly.
  • Ad-Hoc Scans: Perform additional scans after significant changes to the IT environment (e.g., new systems, major updates).
  • Tools:
  • Utilize industry-standard vulnerability scanning tools such as Nessus, Qualys, or OpenVAS.
  • Scope:
  • Scan all networked devices, including servers, endpoints, and IoT devices.
  • Ensure both internal and external scans are conducted to capture a complete picture of vulnerabilities.

1.2 Maintain an Inventory of Assets

  • Asset Discovery:
  • Continuously update and maintain a comprehensive inventory of all hardware, software, and network assets.
  • Use automated tools for asset discovery and inventory management (e.g., ServiceNow CMDB, SolarWinds).
  • Classification:
  • Classify assets based on criticality, such as business importance, data sensitivity, and exposure to external threats.
  • Regular Audits:
  • Conduct regular audits to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the asset inventory.

Step 2: Assessment

2.1 Prioritize Vulnerabilities Based on Risk

  • Risk Scoring:
  • Use the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) to assess the severity of identified vulnerabilities.
  • Consider other factors like asset criticality, threat intelligence, and historical data.
  • Risk Matrix:
  • Develop a risk matrix to categorize vulnerabilities into different risk levels (e.g., Critical, High, Medium, Low).
  • Contextual Assessment:
  • Evaluate the context of each vulnerability (e.g., location, exposure, business impact) to prioritize remediation efforts.

2.2 Evaluate the Impact and Exploitability

  • Impact Assessment:
  • Determine the potential impact of a vulnerability on confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
  • Consider the potential for data breaches, service disruptions, and compliance violations.
  • Exploitability Analysis:
  • Assess the ease with which the vulnerability can be exploited, considering factors such as public exploit availability, skill level required, and network access.
  • Threat Modeling:
  • Use threat modeling techniques to understand potential attack paths and vectors related to each vulnerability.

Step 3: Mitigation

3.1 Apply Patches and Updates

  • Patch Management:
  • Implement a patch management process to ensure timely deployment of security patches and updates.
  • Prioritize patching based on the risk level determined during the assessment phase.
  • Testing:
  • Test patches in a staging environment before deployment to production systems to avoid compatibility issues and downtime.
  • Automation:
  • Use automated tools for patch deployment to streamline the process and reduce manual errors (e.g., Microsoft SCCM, Ansible).

3.2 Implement Compensating Controls

  • When Patches Are Not Available:
  • Implement compensating controls such as network segmentation, application whitelisting, or enhanced monitoring.
  • Temporary Measures:
  • Deploy temporary workarounds, such as disabling vulnerable services or blocking attack vectors, until a permanent fix is available.
  • Continuous Monitoring:
  • Monitor systems for signs of attempted exploitation and adjust controls as necessary.

Step 4: Reporting

4.1 Document Vulnerabilities and Actions Taken

  • Record Keeping:
  • Maintain detailed records of all identified vulnerabilities, including their status, risk assessment, and remediation actions.
  • Vulnerability Tracking:
  • Use a vulnerability management tool or tracking system to monitor the lifecycle of each vulnerability from identification to resolution (e.g., Jira, ServiceNow Vulnerability Response).
  • Compliance:
  • Ensure documentation meets compliance requirements (e.g., PCI DSS, ISO 27001) and is accessible for audits.

4.2 Communicate with Stakeholders

  • Regular Reporting:
  • Provide regular reports to key stakeholders, including IT, security teams, and executive management.
  • Executive Summaries:
  • Create executive summaries that highlight critical vulnerabilities, remediation efforts, and overall risk posture.
  • Incident Response Teams:
  • Collaborate with incident response teams to coordinate actions on vulnerabilities that are actively exploited.

Step 5: Review and Improve

5.1 Review the Effectiveness of Mitigation

  • Post-Mortem Analysis:
  • Conduct post-mortem reviews of significant vulnerabilities to evaluate the effectiveness of the mitigation strategies used.
  • Metrics and KPIs:
  • Track key performance indicators (KPIs) such as time to remediate, number of recurring vulnerabilities, and overall risk reduction.
  • Continuous Improvement:
  • Use lessons learned to refine and improve the vulnerability management process.

5.2 Update the Vulnerability Management Process

  • Regular Updates:
  • Review and update the vulnerability management playbook annually or as needed based on emerging threats and changes in the IT environment.
  • Incorporate Feedback:
  • Gather feedback from security teams, IT staff, and other stakeholders to identify areas for improvement.
  • Stay Informed:
  • Keep up-to-date with the latest vulnerability management best practices, tools, and industry standards.

Tools and Resources

Vulnerability Scanning Tools

  • Nessus: Nessus Vulnerability Scanner
  • Qualys: Qualys Vulnerability Management
  • OpenVAS: OpenVAS Vulnerability Scanner

Patch Management Tools

  • Microsoft SCCM: System Center Configuration Manager
  • Ansible: Ansible Automation

Vulnerability Tracking Tools

  • Jira: Jira Software
  • ServiceNow Vulnerability Response: ServiceNow

Communication and Reporting Tools

  • Power BI: Microsoft Power BI
  • Splunk: Splunk Reporting

Review and Update Procedures

Regular Reviews

  • Frequency: Conduct reviews of the vulnerability management process annually or after significant security incidents.
  • Continuous Feedback: Regularly gather and incorporate feedback from security operations teams and other stakeholders.

Continuous Improvement

  • Process Optimization: Continuously seek opportunities to streamline the vulnerability management process, leveraging new tools and methodologies.
  • Stay Current: Regularly update this playbook to reflect the latest vulnerability management practices, emerging threats, and technological advancements.
